Award.AwardTitle: CCF: AF: Student Travel Support for the 2016 Computational Complexity Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: This award will support student attendance at the IEEE Conference on Computational Complexity (CCC), which will take place May 29 - June 1, 2016, in Tokyo, Japan. CCC is the world's primary conference for research on computational complexity, i.e., the absolute and relative power of computational models under resource constraints. The conference's technical content and international networking opportunities are particularly valuable to students. Because the meeting is outside the U.S., students with accepted papers may have difficulty attending. This award will provide partial support to approximately ten student attendees to defray costs of registration fees, shared hotel rooms, and travel. Co-funding is provided by the Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This student travel support grant provided funding to defray the registration costs and some of the travel expenses of 9 graduate students in various universities in the United States to attend the 2016 Computational Complexity Conference that was held from May 29 to June 1, 2016 in Tokyo, Japan. A small portion of the grant was also used to partially cover the travel expenses of three graduate students in US universities to attend the 2017 Computational Complexity Conference that was held from July 5-9, 2017 in Riga, Latvia.

In addition to paper presentations for the papers accepted to the conference, there was a multi-part tutorial with 6 hours of lectures given by Avi Wigderson in 2017. A rump session was held in 2016 with short, informal presentations of work in progress. The conference's annual business meeting is held each year.  The recipients of the travel allowances supported by this grant were able to participate in all of these activities.

The travel award aimed to support students with a promising future in computational complexity theory from several universities spanning a geographically diverse area. The financial support provided by the grant was crucial in enabling the deserving awardees to participate in, and in most cases present talks at, one of the premier conferences dedicated to the highest quality research in computational complexity.The overseas location of the Computational Complexity Conference in both 2016 and 2017, and the corresponding high costs of air travel, made the student support offered by this award all the more vital.This conference offers one of the key opportunities in the field to network with other researchers and keep up on current research. Further, the students gained valuable experience and insight into the conference publication and presentation process.
